newsitem.title: BELGIUM: France, Germany call for EU "flexibility".
newsitem.headline: France, Germany call for EU "flexibility".

text.p: France and Germany unveiled a long-awaited proposal on Tuesday to allow European Union countries to integrate faster if they wish and not be held up by reluctant partners such as Britain.

French European Affairs Minister Michel Barnier and German State Secretary Werner Hoyer said the issue, known as "flexibility" in EU jargon, was one of the most important facing the bloc as it rewrites its treaty to prepare for the future.
"The system we have set up for 15 countries will certainly not work for 25 or 30," Hoyer said, referring to the planned enlargement of the EU into eastern Europe and the Mediterranean.

The idea is to bring into the EU treaty -- currently under review in the inter-governmental conference (IGC) -- a clause making it clear that some countries can move ahead of others in areas of European cooperation.

Such areas already exist -- ranging from the planned single European currency, which is in the EU treaty, to the Schengen pact on open borders, which is independent -- but the two men said enlargement was likely to mean even more.
"We believe flexibility is going to multiply with enlargement to the East and South," Barnier said.
The bloc is due to bring in as many as a dozen new members early in the next century, making policy making even harder than it is now with 15 countries.

Although not openly targeted at any one country, the idea of flexibility is seen at least in part as a response to longstanding British reluctance to march along with continental Europe towards ever deeper political and economic integration.
Most EU countries, including Britain, generally favour flexibility, but many question how far it should go.
"There is a very strong feeling that it needs to be done carefully," said Noel Dorr, Ireland's IGC negotiator, adding that the Franco-German proposal was by no means the last word.

One fear is that allowing countries to move ahead could damage what has already been achieved by the EU. Another is that a small group of countries would form an inner circle, setting both the rules and agenda for those outside.

Keen integrationists such as Belgium and the Netherlands worry about flexibility leading to the EU being run by a small group of large countries. In a similar fashion, poorer countries such as Spain and Portugal worry about rich partners going their own way.

In one of its more controversial provisions, the Franco-German proposal says that no one country should be allowed to stop others from moving ahead if they want. Britain and others are likely to contest this.

Barnier said it was better for European countries to move ahead within the framework of the European Union than to do so outside, as with Schengen, where non-participating EU countries had no say whatsoever.
Both Barnier and Hoyer were quick to note that their proposal guards against excluding countries which change their mind later and want to join in with the others.
In a related move, Barnier and Hoyer also said France and Germany favoured seeing a reduction in the number of members of the European Commission to make it more efficient in an enlarged bloc.
Small countries such as Ireland and Luxembourg, fearing the loss of representation in the EU executive, oppose such a move.
